body:
Same here under Windows 7 (compare the prompt number):
![snap1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6342379/16684636/7d579760-4506-11e6-85d5-47f3b3771971.png)
![snap2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6342379/16684639/80378c88-4506-11e6-8a31-f80729580f1d.png)
EDIT: Same with `jupyter console` 5.0

OTOH, screenshot with color background:

![clipboard01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/361447/16685012/88daa2a6-4508-11e6-8eed-9194311a7dfd.png)

Here I type `os.<tab>`, then type `path.<tab>` (background isn't cleared)

Same happens with `ptpython`.

I do have bright colors, unlike above reporters, because of my config file:

``` python
from pygments.token import Token

c.TerminalInteractiveShell.highlighting_style_overrides = {
    # IPython overwrites
    Token.Prompt: '#ansigreen',
    Token.PromptNum: '#ansidarkgreen bold',
    Token.OutPrompt: '#ansired',
    Token.OutPromptNum: '#ansidarkred bold',

    Token.Number: '#007700',
    Token.Operator: 'noinherit',
    Token.String: '#BB6622',
    Token.Name.Function: '#2080D0',
    Token.Name.Class: 'bold #2080D0',
    Token.Name.Namespace: 'bold #2080D0'
}
```

I have whole set of this dict copied from prompt-toolkit. It should probably be read on IPython initialization, w/o using config file.

As a side note we could enhance documentation further, with article about customizing colors with newly introduces prompt-toolkit (as mentioned on mailing list).
@klonuo your example uses a diferent console (Windows PowerShell instead of the plain console `cmd.exe`), which might be the reason the colors work for that case (yet background clearing fails).
@xflr6 It's the same console (conhost), but different "shell". I used PS as I knew it had colored background.

It seems that due to the limited color capability of the Windows console (16 color palette) prompt-toolkit is converting the RGB colors to one of the 16 builtin colors but the conversion doesn't seem to get it right for the bright colors.

Also the default Pygments style that is used seems to use some dark colors for example dark blue, which is unusable on a black background terminal. (IPython before 5 used to use the lighter blue). Try reading this:

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2670892/16738983/c36bc87e-47a0-11e6-87cb-72e9a4b98edf.PNG)

This might mean that we need to tweak the default Pygments style used to use lighter colors on dark terminals. Pygments has a TerminalFormatter which has a dark/light bg argument but that class doesn't use the standard Pygments styles which prompt-toolkit does.

For now, unless I built a custom color configuration that essentially restores IPython before 5 colors, this version is unusable on Windows. This can hurt newcomers quite badly too...

I didn't think the colours in the oinspect output (`os.path.exists??`) had changed for 5.0. @Carreau, could your changes to the colour system have affected the ANSI codes we produce? Otherwise, it could be a difference in how the ANSI colour codes are translated to Windows API calls; previously pyreadline was responsible for that translation, now colorama is.

We can't in general detect what the background colour is, so we try to make the default colours visible on both black and white. This is complicated by the fact that the same colours get rendered differently in different systems. Maybe we should assume that there's a dark background on Windows, though - I think it's pretty unusual for Windows users to have a light background command window.

Yeah, no this part is still weird, and still hook into the old PyColorize stuff (that still needs to refactor, and being nuked for next release and use pygments), but right now, yes the "Source" thing is limited to old colors.

![screenshot 2016-07-14 11 31 25](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5316449/16845367/a15e6030-49b6-11e6-841c-b10d6637ca87.png)

Light background 'cmd.exe' terminal in Windows 10. Prompt comes up with a black background. I assume this is a similar issue here, any fix?
Crap, did they really change the default cmd.exe background in Windows 10?

@takluyver No :D @ktritz probably selected white background from one of available colors in console properties, while it's not ColorTable00 (the first color in 16 colors table) which is assumed as background I guess by PTK.

Correct, I changed the cmd.exe color 'defaults' in the system menu. Ipython
doesn't appear to play nice with the change.

On Thu, Jul 14, 2016 at 12:07 PM, klonuo notifications@github.com wrote:

> @takluyver https://github.com/takluyver No :D @ktritz
> https://github.com/ktritz probably selected white background from one
> of available color, while it's not ColorTable00 which is assumed as
> background I guess by PTK.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/9723#issuecomment-232712148,
> or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe/AFEfYc3paFUFzNIQI17aAETBK1yCxutNks5qVl7egaJpZM4JH5ZE
> .

Ah, OK. So we can still assume a black background in general for Windows.

Can you try:
1. `%colors lightbg` - this probably won't work, but you never know.
2. Get some help (e.g. `zip?`) and take a screenshot - those colours are produced in a different way, and I want to see if they work.

![screenshot 2016-07-14 12 46 26](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5316449/16847870/186fb282-49c1-11e6-9ca2-97f5130d7bda.png)

Here you go. The prompt changed color using %colors lightbg, but the background stayed black. Zip help displayed properly.
OK, then it appears that the fixed black background in the prompts is something prompt_toolkit does. @jonathanslenders , have you come across this before?
Having the same issue as @ktritz on Windows 10. IPython 5 seems to reuse the command prompt font color, but overrides the background color to black.

If I understand correctly, people can change the colors in two ways. They can choose another color from the palette to use as foreground/background, but they can also change the value of each color. I think this issue happens in the first case. So far, I haven't been able to work on this issue, but coming Saturday, I should have most of my day for coding. :-)
I'm trying to borrow a windows machine to work on that as well.

Hi all, this commit should fix it: https://github.com/jonathanslenders/python-prompt-toolkit/commit/a9df2a24ed54eae356e622cd4cc0ddf3c4a8c008

Can you try again after checking out the latest commit from prompt-toolkit master?

That fixes the issue for me.

Thanks.

On Wed, Jul 27, 2016 at 12:57 PM, Jonathan Slenders <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Hi all, this commit should fix it: jonathanslenders/python-prompt-toolkit@
> a9df2a2
> https://github.com/jonathanslenders/python-prompt-toolkit/commit/a9df2a24ed54eae356e622cd4cc0ddf3c4a8c008
> 
> Can you try again after checking out the latest commit from prompt-toolkit
> master?
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/9723#issuecomment-235649784,
> or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AFEfYVGFCWSODtnmFxwZbghCI_s9M2mDks5qZ43-gaJpZM4JH5ZE
> .
Thanks @jonathanslenders for another quick response :-)

Hi all,
thank you for all the work.

Is the issue mentioned by ktritz the same as original one? I'm asking, because I've only downloaded the win32_output.py and replaced under site-packages and I'm still having original issue with some colors being unreadable (they were fine in IPython 4).

![s](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8234247/17207335/6a5bfe36-54b4-11e6-8780-f2592fca4c2b.png)

Is there anything I'm missing? Should I customize colors somehow?

Again, please look at another screenshot showing differences - in both cases comment is unreadable.

![s2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8234247/17207486/23be7d7c-54b5-11e6-847b-05ea3558a773.png)

Regards,
Robert

I'm happy for us to import those as the defaults on Windows if it's going to make people's lives easier. Windows users, can you try plugging the colours @jonathanslenders linked into [this code](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/6a38355038fef923c2177159f9f5b9524f6beab2/IPython/terminal/interactiveshell.py#L272) and see if you like the results?

Oh, but that won't affect the `os.paths.exists??` output at all, as far as I'm aware, because that's rendered through a different pathway. Any changes to that are, I guess, the result of differences between pyreadline and colorama (which we switched to). For those, try changing things [here](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/6a38355038fef923c2177159f9f5b9524f6beab2/IPython/utils/PyColorize.py#L125).

Thank you very much for the effort.
However, from my point of view this is a regression, because default colors make some things unreadable (they were fine in 4.x IIRC).
I will try to use provided snippets, but that's not easy - I have to put some code in some files to have desired effect:
- is there any single place to change some 'theme'?
- entering "ipython customize colors" leads to nowhere. I couldn't find a single place describing format and place which I should change:
  -- should that be console (http://jupyter-console.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config_options.html) or terminal (http://ipython.readthedocs.io/en/stable/config/options/terminal.html)
  -- what's the format, as plain "InteractiveShell.colors='Linux'" in .jupyter_console_config.py leads to NameError

Current status is that after entering %colors linux docstrings are more readable, but that doesn't solve prompt issue:

In [7]: from collect

collect colors are different than those in docstrings

Sorry for being chaotic and/or inaccurate, I'm writing things from ordinary Windows ipython/jupyter perspective.

Regards,
Robert

We have two separate colouring systems because of how the code has developed; we know this makes it confusing, and we do want to unify them, but that's where we are now.

None of the core developers normally use Windows, so it's easier for Windows-specific problems to creep in, especially in things like colours that can't easily be tested. I'll try to boot up my Windows partition later today and have a fiddle.

Please let me know if I can help further in any way.

Robert

As a side note when I invoked "%colors linux" then things in docstrings were better (but those in prompt weren't).
I've tried to have the same effect with:

c = get_config()
c.InteractiveShell.colors='linux'

in jupyter_console_config.py, but despite the file being executed (as I could see from some errors), there was no effect at all. That's not limited to colors, though, because "c.InteractiveShell.prompt_in1 = 'ala '" was a no-op as well.

Robert
The colours in the inspection output are generated in IPython, not jupyter_console. The `prompt_in1` setting is no longer used since the switch to prompt_toolkit.
